title: VLM Art Analysis
summary: Analyze and compare the capabilities of Microsoft's Florence-2-base and Alibaba Cloud's Qwen2-VL-2B visual language models in processing, comprehending, and explaining various artworks across different styles and time periods, highlighting their strengths and limitations in art analysis.
origin_content:
# Introduction

VLM Art Analysis by Microsoft Florence-2 and Alibaba Cloud Qwen2-VL/n/nThis study‚Äôs goal is to analyze and compare the results obtained by foundation models Microsoft‚Äôs Florence-2 and Alibaba Cloud‚Äôs Qwen2-VL to process and explain artworks./n/nFlorence-2 has been introduced by Microsoft in June 2024. A smaller-scale model with zero-shot and fine-tuning capabilities, it is designed to be able to detect, caption and segment elements in pictures from text-prompt and task instructions. FLD-5B consists of 5.4 billion comprehensive visual annotations on 126 million images, ‚Äúusing an iterative strategy of automated image annotation and model refinement‚Äù. Florence-2 has been trained on a sequence-to-sequence structure. It is considered a ‚Äústrong vision foundation model contender‚Äù./n/nQwen2-VL is the latest version on the VLM in the Qwen group, released on August 30, 2024 by Alibaba Cloud. It ‚Äúachieves state-of-the-art performance on visual understanding benchmarks, including MathVista, DocVQA, RealWorldQA, MTVQA‚Äù. The model can comprehend and analyze even long videos, be used on a cellphone, and support various languages, mainly English and European and Asian languages. It is described as being able to "handle arbitrary image resolutions, mapping them into a dynamic number of visual tokens, offering a more human-like visual processing experience‚Äù. Its Multimodal Rotary Position Embedding (M-ROPE) can ‚Äúdecompose positional embedding into parts to capture 1D textual, 2D visual, and 3D video positional information, enhancing its multimodal processing capabilities‚Äù. Qwen2-VL is an open-source models which include Qwen2-VL-2B and Qwen2-VL-7B, under the Apache 2.0 license, and Qwen2-VL-72B under the Qwen license. The models are integrated with Hugging Face Transformers, vLLM, and other third-party frameworks./n/nFor this study, I have used the Florence-2-base and Qwen2-VL-2B models on Google Colab, as standard, easily accessible and affordable models in term of space needed or in price as the GPU is free on Google Colab./n/nThe purpose of this study is to assess how Florence-2-base and Qwen2-VL-2B are capable to process, comprehend, and explain artworks and to detect objects within the image. We will compare the results obtained with the two models for several artworks, from different styles, time periods and levels of notoriety. After studying and comparing the results obtained, we will be able to attest of the efficiency of these two models, to accomplish different tasks applied to artistic works./n

# Analysis of Florence-2-base ability to process and describe artworks.

/n/nThe first model I used to analyze and describe artworks was Florence-2-base. A smaller yet efficient visual language model, Florence was able to identify some of the main objects in an image without any task instruction (and locate them even more easily with the prompt indications)./n/nFlorence-2-base was not able to recognize the artwork nor the artist themselves. It also had difficulties to process certain types of objects: it ran into issues to differentiate objects with a similar appearance. It also had trouble defining a particular time period, based on the elements (clothes, architecture etc.) from the painting. In some cases, it easily defined some of the less central elements, while not being able to notice the most central of them at all./n/nThe analysis of The Lady And The Unicorn (circa 1500) by Florence-2-base./n/nAn analysis of the Lady and The Unicorn medieval tapestry successfully defined the main figure as a ‚Äúmedieval woman‚Äù and the lion but was not able to detect other elements without being pushed by task instructions./n/nThe results obtained with the ‚ÄúDense region caption‚Äù command on Florence-2./n/nFlorence-2 objects detection results after using the ‚ÄúCAPTION_TO_PHRASE_GROUNDING" command to force it to define more elements from the painting./n/nThe description delivered by Florence-2-base from the Lady and The Unicorn tapestry is the following:/n/n"MORE _DETAILED_CAPTION":‚ÄôThe image is is a painting. The painting is red and blue. There are trees on the left and right side of the painting. There is a woman in a red dress standing in front of a blue tent. The woman is holding a sword in her right hand. On the left side there is a white lion. The lion is standing on its hind legs.‚Äô}/n/nWhile it successfully recognized the main colors and the natural and architectural elements from the tapestry, Florence-2-base seemed to have issues identifying the unicorn (only mentioning the lion) or might have mistaken the unicorn for the lion as it is described as ‚Äúwhite‚Äù in the description. It is worth mentioning as well that it mentions a ‚Äúsword‚Äù the woman is holding that is not in fact present in the image, maybe confusing it with the hand of the woman reaching for her jewelry box. It completely missed in its description the other woman next to her./n/nAs we can see in this image prompted by the "CAPTION_TO_PHRASE_GROUNDING" command, in Florence-2-base analysis of the Lady and The Unicorn tapestry, the model especially drew its attention to natural elements (trees) and a large number of ‚Äúlions‚Äù that it used to define almost all the animals present in the picture./n/nThe analysis of Raphael‚Äôs The School of Athens by Florence-2-base./n/nThe analysis and description of Raphael‚Äôs The School of Athens made by Florence-2-base is quite representative of what the model is capable of. The Italian Renaissance fresco was painted by 1508 and 1512 and it is currently exhibited in the Vatican Apostolic Palace./n/nWhile it successfully recognized some elements (especially related to the architecture and decor), it had trouble identifying several objects and seemed to get confused by the large variety of human and human-looking figures, in this case the statues on the columns in the artwork. The model kept on mistaking the human figures with these statues and was not able to identify the name of the figures even with prompt indications (also because there are many characters)./n/nThe main focus of Florence-2‚Äôs attention was definitely the architectural, inanimate elements, such as the columns and elements of decoration./n/nIn a first attempt at object detection, Florence-2-base defined each character as a ‚Äúperson‚Äù (including the statues surrounding the scene)./n/nIn a second attempt and even with instructions Florence-2-base made the same mistake but the other way around, defining almost all the figures, living and inanimate, as ‚Äúsculptures‚Äù./n/nFlorence-2-base seemed to have an issue to detect abstract and conceptual elements. Like we have just seen, it had to be indicated by prompt the presence of the ‚Äúunicorn‚Äù to define it for the Lady and The Unicorn./n/nIn a similar way, in The School of Athens, the model did not manage to detect the figures of the philosophers and to define them as such. It referred to them in a first attempt as ‚ÄúGreekengers‚Äù (when prompted to detect a group of "Greek philosophers assembled‚Äù)./n/nWhen pushed with instructions to define a ‚Äúgroup of philosophers‚Äù, Florence-2 did not manage to detect the philosophers but instead defined one of the statue as ‚Äúa group of chimneys‚Äù (?)./n/nIt finally successfully defined the category of the members of the group when prompted to describe a ‚Äúgroup of people who teach philosophy‚Äù./n/nThe analysis of William Turner‚Äôs Rome From Mount Aventine (1835) by Florence-2-base./n/nI used Florence-2-base to detect objects and describe a more recent figurative work. In this case, I chose a James Mallord William‚Äôs Turner painting, Rome from Mount Aventine (1835, Private Collection). In a less crowded image and with more recognizable and clearly defined elements, the model managed to detect objects more successfully./n/nHere are the three descriptions Florence-2-base produced on the Turner‚Äôs painting, with diverse results from the level of details asked:/n/nWith the "CAPTION" command: "A painting of a river with boats in the water"./n/nWith the "DETAILED_CAPTION" command: In this image we can see a painting. In the painting there are boats on the water. Also there are buildings. And there is a tree. On the right side there are two persons"./n/nWith the "MORE_DETAILED_CAPTION" command: "A painting of a river with boats in the water. There is a tall tree next to the river. There are two people standing on a rock next to a tree"./n/nInterestingly enough, the "DETAILED_CAPTION" produced more content than the "MORE_DETAILED_CAPTION", where the only new details Florence-2-base added were the size of the tree and the mentions of a rock (while forgetting to mention the building again in this description). As we have seen in our other examples, Florence-2-base is definitely more focused on the architectural and natural elements. It failed again to recognize a definite time period or the city represented in the painting (in this case, Rome)./n/nThe analysis of Claude Monet Luncheon on the grass (1865-1866) by Florence-2-base./n/nFollowing the analysis of a classical Renaissance artwork and a 19th landscape painting, it seemeed interesting to pursue the exploration of Florence-2-base art analytic abilities with the example of an artwork from the Impressionist period: in this case, Luncheon on the grass by Claude Monet./n/nAs we can see in this image, the model had trouble adjusting to the presence of numerous characters. If, for once, it focused more on the figures than on the landscape and natural elements, it still had difficulties to define the characters and the objects around them. This is understandable as the painting is less figurative and the objects are less defined than in the previous examples we used (whether for the Raphael's fresco or the Turner painting.)/n/nHere is the following descriptions given by the model, with diverse levels of detailing:/n/nWith the "CAPTION" command: "A painting of a group of people sitting around a table"./n/nWith the "DETAILED_CAPTION" command: "In this image we can see a painting. In the painting there are people. Also there is a table. On the table there are bottles, plates, food items and many other items. In that there are many trees"./n/nWith the "MORE_DETAILED_CAPTION": "A painting of people sitting around a table. There is a woman in a white dress sitting in front of a white table cloth. There are bottles on top of the table"./n/nAs we can see, Florence-2-base had difficulties analyzing the picnic concept and scene. It seemed to refer to it as a "table". Many repetitions were found throughout the descriptions (such as "In this image we can see a painting. In the painting there are people"). Also in these descriptions, the model had difficulties once again to define the figures, only identifying one or refering to them as a group./n/nThe analysis of Wassily Kandinsky‚Äôs Impression III (Concert) (1911) by Florence-2-base./n/nWe used as another example the abstract painting by Wassily Kandinsky Impression III (Concert) from 1911. Applied to this artwork, Florence-2-base artistic analysis was not very successful./n/nIn its description, the model managed to identify shapes and the right colors but mistakenly defined the figures as a single ‚Äúflower‚Äù and then as a group of ‚Äúflowers‚Äù, instead of what they really are: a very abstract group of human figures./n/nWith the "MORE_DETAILED_CAPTION" command:"A painting is done in black, white, blue, red and yellow. The painting has a black outline on a white background. There are black dots on the white face of the painting. On the left side there is a red, white and black flower. The flowers are in various colors. There is a circle on the yellow background"./n/nFlorence-2-base did not manage to detect objects easily in this case of an abstract painting,. With the "DENSE_REGION_CAPTION" command, it defined the entire image as a painting, without detecting any other elements./n/nConclusion of this study of Florence-2-base abilities to process and analyze artworks./n/nThe artworks analysis we made with Florence-2-base lead to this conclusion: in general, the model is efficient to identify objects but there are mistakes (even when guided by instructions) and issues to identify figures, places or time periods. The model had difficulties to differentiate objects when they looked similar, for example it was not able to tell the difference between a person and a statue. It also had trouble recognizing figures and categorizing them, especially when there were too many of them./n/nThere are limits to the model‚Äôs interpretations, especially with less figurative and abstract overcrowded images. I noticed that the more the items were described specifically in the instructions, the more Florence-2-base got lost to define the objects. The results are good to have a general idea of a setting, a short description, or to detect certain types of objects (in particular architectural and natural elements, animals etc.). But when asked by prompt to define and differentiate more extensively described objects and figures, it led to mixed, confused and incorrect final results, even with spatial indications./n

# Analysis of Qwen2-VL-2B ability to process and describe artworks.

/n/nI followed the artwork analysis with Florence-2-base by another, this time with Qwen2-VL-2B. The goal was to see how the model managed to detect elements, analyze and explain artworks and in some extent assess how it fared in artworks‚Äô analysis as compared to Florence-2-base./n/nQwen2-VL-2B delivered impressive results to analyze and explain the paintings, especially the most famous ones in the selection. In general there were minimal or even no instructions on my part. The model was fully able to produce a description with the correct time period, place or subject./n/nThe analysis of Raphael‚Äôs The School of Athens by Qwen2-VL-2B./n/nAfter analyzing the Raphael‚Äôs The School of Athens fresco with Florence-2-base, it seemed necessary to follow with an analysis of the very same artwork by Qwen2-VL-2B, in order to see the differences in the art analysis delivered by these two models./n/nWhen asked to explain the image, without giving any instructions, the model produced the following long description./n/nQwen2-VL-2B identified a correct general time period (‚Äúfrom the ancient Greek or Roman period‚Äù), used a large descriptive vocabulary in keeping with the terms usually used in art history descriptions (‚Äúforeground‚Ä¶middle ground‚Ä¶background‚Ä¶The architectural elements, such as the columns and arches, add to the grandeur of the scene‚Ä¶the painting is a detailed and intricate representation of a classical setting‚Ä¶a grand and ornate architectural backdrop‚Äù). It also tried to identify different figures and successfully differentiated them from the sculptures, as opposed to Florence-2-base. While the model noticed the ‚Äúclassical attire‚Äù of the characters, it still did not manage to define them as philosophers, instead referring to their activity as: ‚Äúengaged in a discussion‚Ä¶a meeting or a council, with the figures appearing to be in a deep conversation or debate‚Ä¶ some of whom are engaged in writing or reading‚Ä¶ The figures are engaged in various activities, including conversation, writing, and possibly performing a ritual or ceremony‚Ä¶ the overall atmosphere of the painting is one of intellectual and communal activity‚Ä¶‚Äù. It seems as of today, neither Florence-2-base nor Qwen2-VL-2B were able to define what a philosopher is./n/nWhile it made an accurate, general description Qwen2-VL-2B did start to go in a loop, for example when describing the activity the group was doing. Similar to Florence-2-base, it put a major focus on architectural elements. It is interesting to see how the model tried to give its own interpretation of the artwork./n

# The analysis of Wassily Kandinsky‚Äôs Pastorale (1911) by Qwen2-VL-2B.

/n/nThe next artwork I used as example to assess Qwen2-VL-2B art analysis abilities was an abstract painting. In this case, the painting was Wassily Kandinsky‚Äôs Pastorale (1911), from the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York./n/nIn its second attempt at describing a painting, and this time from a very different style, genre and period, Qwen2-VL-2B managed to successfully identify the artist (without any indications on my part). On the contrary, it wasn‚Äôt able to deliver an accurate description and interpretation of the painting. It was indeed identified as a painting named Flamingo (a subject Kandinsky has never tried to paint as far as my research go)./n/nInterestingly enough, the description made by Qwen2-VL of the Kandinsky painting is based on a central flamingo figure from which the model went as far as giving the painting its title: ‚ÄúThe central figure is a flamingo, which is depicted with a blue and green body and a pink head. The flamingo is surrounded by [‚Ä¶] including a blue and green bird, a pink and white pink, and a blue and a green flower‚Äù. The model missed out on the group of four human figures, occupying the major part of the artwork, as well as figures of animals, trees and landscape in the background. It defined the flamingo based on a mix of colorful elements between the grass, the water and a pink shape, that it then re-used to define the birds surrounding this ‚Äúflamingo‚Äù./n/nWhile Qwen2-VL-2B was very successful at identifying the artist of this painting (and surprisingly so!), it has to be said it didn‚Äôt proceed to deliver a very accurate description of the artwork, missing out on the main figures and finding the meaning and title of the painting from background elements mixed together without making any sense./n/nThe analysis of Claude Monet Luncheon on the Grass (1865-1866) by Qwen2-VL-2B./n/nThe third attempt at painting analysis with Qwen2-VL was made with a less abstract painting. Still, its more Impressionistic style led to confusion for the model in order to define the objects. For Claude Monet‚Äôs Luncheon on the Grass, that was already analyzed by Florence-2-base, the description given by Qwen2-VL-2B of the artwork was extensive and overall accurate, defining the right time period as the late 19th century (apparently based on the clothing style) and correctly describing the various figures in the painting. It did, although, make a mistake by indicating the presence of a ‚Äúchild‚Äù ‚Äî in fact, nowhere to be seen on the actual painting./n/nThe figures in the Monet painting being less defined and identifiable (even if not as abstract as in the Kandinsky example), they created a bit of challenge for Qwen2-VL-2B in its description. While most of it is quite relevant: ‚Äúsuggesting that the scene might be set in the late 19th century. The overall atmosphere is relaxed and leisurely, with the group enjoying a picnic in a serene forest setting‚Äù, it is worth noticing that after correctly describing the tablecloth at the first as a ‚Äútablecloth spread out on the ground‚Äù for the picnic on the grass, the model then described it as a ‚Äútable‚Äù: ‚ÄúOn the table‚Ä¶ There are two people sitting at the table‚Ä¶ Another person is standing near the table‚Äù./n/nOnce again, Qwen2-VL-2B focused its description on natural elements: ‚Äúa natural, outdoor seating with lush green trees and foliage in the background‚Äù./n/nThe analysis of Claude Monet Impression, Sunrise (1872) and Vincent Van Gogh The Starry Night by Qwen2-VL-2B./n/nWhen tasked to identify the most famous artworks of artists with a high notoriety, Qwen2-VL-2B was extremely successful at instantly recognizing them. It completely identified Vincent Van Gogh‚Äôs The Starry Night (1889, MoMA) and Monet‚Äôs Impression, Sunrise (1872, Mus√©e Marmottan) without any instructions. The model managed to identify both the paintings and the painters names, which might have been thanks to the signature or by the fact these are two commonly well-known art pieces, but the descriptions in the results were still impressive. Both were accurate, concise and well-written, in the usual style for an art piece description, and even categorized the artworks in their artists' career./n/nFor the Monet‚Äôs masterpiece, the model even correctly managed to identify the movement to which it belonged, without any instructions: ‚ÄúThe painting is characterized by its loose, impressionistic style, which captures the fleeting effects of light and color in nature. The use of bright, contrasting colors and the use of brushstrokes to create a sense of movement and energy are prominent features of Monet‚Äôs painting‚Ä¶it is considered one of Monet‚Äôs most iconic works‚Äù./n/nFor Vincent Van Gogh's The Starry Night, the model succeeded in identifying the artwork, the artist as well as replacing the painting in the context of Van Gogh's career and assess its impact in art history./n/nAs shown in the description, Qwen2-VL-2B successfully recognized the subject: "the painting depicts a starry night sky filled with sizzling, luminous, stars, creating a sense of motion and dynamism". The model stresses numerous times the presence of "swirling" figures, the contrast of light/dark in the painting and the twisted shapes, in a repetitive manner. It did succeed in delivering a convincing analysis of the artwork: "dynamism. The sky is dominated by a large, bright yellow star, which stands out against the dark blue background... In the foreground, there is a tall, dark tree with a gnarled trunk and a curved, twisted shape... Below the tree, there is a small village with a church steeple". What is very interesting is to realize Qwen2-VL abilities to situate the artwork not only in Van Gogh's production, but in art history itself: "Overall, "Starry Night" is a masterpiece of Van Gogh's style, and it is widely regarded as one of the most iconic and influential paintings in the history of art"./n/nAs for Monet's Impression, Sunrise analysis, it has to be recalled that Qwen2-VL-2B offered this complete description without any instructions, indications or suggestions on my part./n/nThe analysis of Claude Monet San Giorgio Maggiore at Dusk (1908-1912) by Qwen2-VL-2B./n/nFor our next example to analyze another painting by Claude Monet (this time later in his career) with Qwen2-VL-2B, the artwork chosen was San Giorgio Maggiore at Dusk (1908-1912). In this case, Qwen2-VL was not able to identify either the painter, the painting or the setting of Venice./n/nThe model delivered a brief, concise yet descriptive explanation of the painting with an eloquent style: ‚ÄúThe sky is painted in warm hues of orange and yellow, transitioning into darker shades of blue and purple as it descends‚Äù. Even if it did not identify the general setting in Venice or Italy (‚Äúsituated on a hill or a raised platform. The foreground features a body of water, likely a river or a lake, reflecting the colors of the sky and the building‚Äù), the model did manage to recognize the building as a church/cathedral ‚Äî and this rightly so: ‚ÄúThe building appears to be a church or a cathedral‚Äù./n/nIf the aesthetic description and analysis was very good, the model did not‚Äôt succeed in this example to correctly identify the main elements of the paintings, nor the name of the artist./n/nConclusion of this study of Qwen2-VL-2B abilities to process and analyze artworks./n/nGenerally speaking, Qwen2-VL-2B proved to be very successful at identifying the painting‚Äôs subject, as well as the name of the artist. It also managed to recognize the name of the most famous paintings, without any instructions and information given on my part (apart from asking it to "Explain the image‚Äù). It was able to link artworks to a particular movement. On the contrary, it was not as efficient to recognize lesser known paintings or ones that were less representative of an artist‚Äôs style./n/nThe results obtained to describe figurative paintings were usually much more accurate than in the case of abstract paintings. For the Impressionist and Post-Impressionist art paintings, the results were mixed: extremely relevant and accurate in the case of the most famous artworks, in this case Monet's Impression, Sunrise and Van Gogh's The Starry Night ; a blend of accurate elements and errors or lack of object detections for the other two Monet paintings./n/nThe descriptions of architectural and natural elements were usually the most relevant, also as showed in the results of the analysis by Florence-2-base. In the case of Qwen2-VL-2B, the objects were usually very well detected (church, building, figures‚Ä¶), even with some minors mistakes. It also created some elements that were not present in the painting out of thin air. In its descriptions, the model used the terms and style commonly used for artworks analysis in art history, which is impressive./n/nConclusion/n/nTo conclude, the best results overall to analyze, describe and explain artworks were obtained by Qwen2-VL-2B, which is not surprising as it a larger-scale model, compared to Florence-2-base, and with different goals in visual analysis. There were still mistakes in Qwen2-VL-2B descriptions: the model had difficulties with some languages (for example, in French). It also would go in a loop when it had troubles deciphering and defining some elements. In any case, it is definitely impressive in its abilities to identify an artist, a painting, an artistic movement, a definite time period and the subject of the artwork, especially for the paintings that are more figurative. The style used by Qwen2-VL is also as accurate to describe artworks as the style used in art history studies./n/nFlorence-2-base is successful at attaining its goal to be a model trained to detect and pinpoint the main objects in an image. It successfully defined elements, without any instructions, especially the ones related to nature and architecture, and this more successfully in less crowded scenes. While it managed to recognize animals than human figures more easily, it did have difficulties in both cases when the figures were similar-looking, doing the same activity or were standing and sitting close together./n/nFlorence-2-base had issues to differentiate inanimate objects with human features ‚Äî such as statues ‚Äî and human figures, and this even if pushed through prompts instructions. It was not able to acknowledge certain types of characteristics (such as the time period) and activities (for example to define an occupation such as the ‚Äúphilosophers‚Äù in the Raphael's fresco). The results were generally better with the paintings that were more figurative and with more defined shapes than with abstract art. That being said, Florence-2-base might benefit from fine tuning to specifically process works of art, in order to avoid issues such as the ones encountered during this study./n/nAs expected, Qwen2-VL-2B managed longer and more complete descriptions of the artworks. Florence-2-B proved to be a relevant visual model, in its abilities to detect objects and successfully describe the artworks, even if more succintly. It remains to see how both models would compare with their other versions, such as Florence-2-large and Qwen2-VL-7B, and how will they evolve with time to achieve more extensive, better, zero-shot results./n/nIn the course of this study, I also had the opportunity to process images containing only elements of text: while there was in the selection of the paintings analyzed by Florence-2-base and Qwen2-VL parts containing text (signatures etc.), I also used as examples some images presenting only text. In this case, I used handwritten letters in French and English. While the results were definitely more successful to process English letters, there were still difficulties to explain their content and decipher the handwriting, especially when it was not very clear, leading to loop issues. In the case of Florence-2-base, the results did not even manage to understand the French words at all, leading to an incoherent sentence in French based English-sounding words. Qwen2-VL-2B also had trouble understanding the letter in French and only managed to comprehend a part of it./n/nThus, it would be interesting for a next study to compare the results by Florence-2 and Qwen2-VL to analyze and process images containing text, also with CVAT.it. The goal would be to see how the models will manage to transcribe, decipher and explain images solely containing written text, whether handwritten or printed, with OCR processing. This will be the subject for my next article./n/nFAQ/n

# How do Florence-2-base and Qwen2-VL-2B compare when analyzing artworks?

/n/nFlorence-2-base and Qwen2-VL-2B are both successful to analyze artworks, detect the main objects/subjects and deliver relevant descriptions, on a variety of painting genres. As a larger-scale model, Qwen2-VL-2B has more abilities to deliver longer descriptions and it was also able to identify the name of some of the artists and paintings without any instructions, just based on the artworks. Florence-2-base did also manage to successfully define the main objects in an image, especially for the most figurative ones. Qwen2-VL-2B was extremely accurate at identifying the most famous Impressionist and post-Impressionist paintings used in this study but generated mixed results for the other Impressionist, lesser famous artworks, that it was not even able to identify. Both models encountered problems with abstract art./n

title: MicroJAX
summary: Write a comprehensive explanation of how to build a micro JAX-like transformation engine, focusing on function transformation capabilities and automatic differentiation. Include implementations for forward and reverse mode autodiff, along with examples of their usage and composition.
origin_content:
# Introduction

Community Article Published August 25, 2024/n/nThis is a micro dev blog on how to build a micro Jax / mlx-like transformation engine, because I don't find anything easy that explains function transformation engines on the internet. Just like Karpathy-senpai's micrograd is a simple version of PyTorch, microjax is a simpler version of Jax./n/nGithub: microjax - leave a ‚≠ê if you find this useful./n

# ü§ó blog is mirror of pythonstuff

/n/nWarning: This is made for understanding with incrementally increasing complexity, not absolute correctness./n/nNow there exits Autodidax, but its pretty hard, with heavy words and lambda functions. I had idea bcs of this :3/n/nWay back, Google was TensorFlow-pilled. Google has a custom chip TPU and XLA, a really smart linear algebra compiler to make it go brr, but TensorFlow was awful to work with. Other growing frameworks like PyTorch had a dynamic nature that wasn't that great. Jax was an experimental project from Google that converts Python traces to XLA, which can be compiled with MLIR and run on accelerators like GPUs and TPUs. We can divide Jax into two parts: function transformation and XLA compiler. Function transformation gives us the ability to calculate gradients, Hessians, and define vmap-like transformations, while XLA IR conversion gives us speed. Here we will only cover a simple function transformation engine, so the X part of Jax is not here, but hey, MLX has X so I don't care, I'm calling it microjax. Although Jax has gone more mainstream recently, the story of Jax goes back to autograd./n/nAutograd had a more novel goal. You need to calculate gradients for machine learning or scientific computing, and Python is the language of scientific computing. So let's make Python differentiable, but how can one make a high-level, interpreted language like Python differentiable?/n

# Base Interpretor

/n/nfirst we will start primitive, this are fundameation ops in jax land all all other oprator will be base on it, btw this is scalr valued only so its more easy to understand, (np array are techincally supported but i will not define array ops for simplicity)/n/nfrom __future__ import annotations import math from contextlib import contextmanager from typing import Any, Callable/n/nclass OPS: ADD = "add" MUL = "mul" NEG = "neg" RECIP = "recip" EXP = "exp" SIN = "sin"/n/nYou only need this ops for most this, you can define your own if that tickles your fancy/n/nLets start with base interpretor, this is like abstract class,/n/nclass Interpreter: def __init__(self, level: int = 0, *args, **kwargs): self.level = level def process_primitive(self, prim, boxes, params): "in this function, either you process primitives or you unbox and send to lower level interpreter" raise NotImplementedError/n/nIn JAX, this is called a Trace. A Trace keeps track of tracers, which are simply boxed values. We put values in boxes along with some extra information like whether we need to calculate gradients or other things like shape and which interpreter to use. For each unique type of transformation, we will have a box of that type and an interpreter of that type./n/nNow we will have multiple interpreters. To know in which context the boxed values should evaluate, we need to keep track of interpreters. We will do that with the most common data structure: stack./n/nSTACK: list[Interpreter] = [] def push_interpreter(interpreter: Interpreter): STACK.append(interpreter) return STACK def pop_interpreter() -> Interpreter: return STACK.pop() def interpreter_context(interpreter_type: Interpreter): stack_item = interpreter_type(level=len(STACK)) push_interpreter(stack_item) try: yield stack_item finally: pop_interpreter()/n/nNow let's define Box, Box (tracer) is what actually flows through functions you define. We need to override some dunder methods to make it work with Python./n/nclass Box: _interpreter: Interpreter def aval(self): raise NotImplementedError def __add__(self, other): return add(self, other) def __radd__(self, other): return add(other, self) def __mul__(self, other): return mul(self, other) def __rmul__(self, other): return mul(other, self) def __neg__(self): return neg(self) def __sub__(self, other): return add(self, neg(other)) def __rsub__(self, other): return add(other, neg(self)) def __truediv__(self, other): return mul(self, recip(other)) def __rtruediv__(self, other): return mul(other, recip(self)) def __iadd__(self, other): return add(self, other) def __imul__(self, other): return mul(self, other) def __isub__(self, other): return add(self, neg(other)) def __itruediv__(self, other): return mul(self, recip(other))/n/nwe are almost done with abstract classes just few helper/n/nwhen function recives multiple boxed values, we need to find top level interpreter for them,/n/ndef find_top_interpreter(args): """ find the top level interpreter for the given arguments """ interpreters = [] for item in args: if isinstance(item, Box): interpreters.append(item._interpreter) if interpreters: return max(interpreters, key=lambda x: x.level) return STACK[0]/n/nif one values in box at level 2 and another at level 3, we need to raise them to level 3, with this function/n/ndef full_raise(interpreter: Interpreter | Any, out) -> Box | JVPBox: """ if interpreter need values boxed if out is not boxed, box it (using interpreter.pure) ie. raise out to the box level """ if not isinstance(out, Box): return interpreter.pure(out) return out/n/nEach boxed value will have an interpreter assigned to it. Each interpreter will have a level indicating its position in the stack. The find_top_interpreter function will find the highest level interpreter among them all. full_raise will raise up a value to the current interpreter level in the stack. bind_single is just a small wrapper to handle the tuple returned by bind./n/ndef bind(prim, *args, **params): interpreter = find_top_interpreter(args) boxes = [full_raise(interpreter, arg) for arg in args] outs = interpreter.process_primitive(prim, boxes, params) return [out for out in outs] def bind_single(prim, *args, **params): (out,) = bind(prim, *args, **params) return out/n

# bind is importent function, which will call interpreters

/n/nPrimitives/n/nThese are building blocks, all other functions will build on top of these. I like to call them mock functions as they don't really compute anything; they are more like routers for boxes to interpreters./n/ndef add(*args): return bind_single(OPS.ADD, *args) def mul(*args): return bind_single(OPS.MUL, *args) def neg(x): return bind_single(OPS.NEG, x) def recip(x): return bind_single(OPS.RECIP, x) def exp(x): return bind_single(OPS.EXP, x) def sin(x): return bind_single(OPS.SIN, x)/n/nPrimitives are like mock functions. When you call mul(Box1(3), Box1(2)), this will find interpreters for Box1(3) and Box1(2), then find the interpreter with the highest level among them. It will unbox these values and tell that interpreter to process those primitives. For every op type, there is a primitive op function./n/nComposite functions build on top of primitives. As long as you can express your function in terms of primitives, you can use arbitrarily complicated functions./n/ndef cos(x): return sin(x + math.pi / 2) def sigmoid(x): return 1 / (1 + exp(-x)) def tanh(x): return 2 * sigmoid(2 * x) - 1 def silu(x): return x * sigmoid(x)/n

# Eval Interpreter

/n/nEven if we have nice abstraction layers, at the end someone has to run add or mul functions. This will be done by the eval interpreter. We will first define evaluation rules and then the eval interpreter./n/nclass EvalRules: def __init__(self): self.rules = { OPS.ADD: self.add, OPS.MUL: self.mul, OPS.NEG: self.neg, OPS.RECIP: self.recip, OPS.EXP: self.exp, OPS.SIN: self.sin, } def __getitem__(self, op): return self.rules[op] def add(self, primals, *args): x, y = primals return [x + y] def mul(self, primals, *args): x, y = primals return [x * y] def neg(self, primals, *args): (x,) = primals return [-x] def recip(self, primals, *args): (x,) = primals return [1 / x] def exp(self, primals, *args): (x,) = primals return [math.exp(x)] def sin(self, primals, *args): (x,) = primals return [math.sin(x)]/n/nWe don't expect any boxed values to be passed to the eval interpreter, so we can just call functions directly on values. It's straightforward: take args and return the result./n/nclass EvalInterpreter(Interpreter): def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): super().__init__(*args, **kwargs) self.rules = EvalRules() def pure(self, val): return val def process_primitive(self, prim, values, params): return self.rules[prim](values, *params)/n/nBasic interpreter is EvalInterpreter, Now we run run basic program, since evalution are end of primitive we will push eval interpreter at bottom of stack,/n/npush_interpreter(EvalInterpreter())/n

# Now we can kick off basic program,

/n/ndef func(x): return sin(x)*exp(x) + tanh(x) x = 3.14 func(x)/n/n1.033056645880499/n/nyou may feel like this ^ but this abstractions will be used to build more complex AD/n

# Suppose we have function y=D(C(B(A(x)))) y = D(C(B(A(x)))) y=D(C(B(A(x))))

/n/nif x is a vector then its gradient is can be computed by jacobian matrix/n

# ‚àÇy‚àÇx=J‚ãÖv \frac{\partial y}{\partial x} = J \cdot v ‚àÇx‚àÇy‚Äã=J‚ãÖv

/n/nif you dont know what is jacobian matrix, its just a matrix of partial derivatives, watch is for if need refresh link/n/nNow we can define our function in terms of primitives./n/ny=D(c),c=C(b),b=B(a),a=A(x) y = D(c), \quad c = C(b), \quad b = B(a), \quad a = A(x) y=D(c),c=C(b),b=B(a),a=A(x)/n/nsame way we can define jacobian matrix as product of derivatives of each function, or mathematically we can define big jacobian by chain rule. F‚Ä≤(x)=‚àÇy‚àÇx F'(x) = \frac{\partial y}{\partial x} F‚Ä≤(x)=‚àÇx‚àÇy‚Äã ‚àÇy‚àÇx=‚àÇy‚àÇc‚ãÖ‚àÇc‚àÇb‚ãÖ‚àÇb‚àÇa‚ãÖ‚àÇa‚àÇx \frac{\partial y}{\partial x}= \frac{\partial y}{\partial c} \cdot \frac{\partial c}{\partial b} \cdot \frac{\partial b}{\partial a} \cdot \frac{\partial a}{\partial x} ‚àÇx‚àÇy‚Äã=‚àÇc‚àÇy‚Äã‚ãÖ‚àÇb‚àÇc‚Äã‚ãÖ‚àÇa‚àÇb‚Äã‚ãÖ‚àÇx‚àÇa‚Äã/n/n‚àÇy‚àÇc=D‚Ä≤(c)‚àÇc‚àÇb=C‚Ä≤(b)‚àÇb‚àÇa=B‚Ä≤(a)‚àÇa‚àÇx=A‚Ä≤(x) \frac{\partial y}{\partial c} = D'(c) \quad \frac{\partial c}{\partial b} = C'(b) \quad \frac{\partial b}{\partial a} = B'(a) \quad \frac{\partial a}{\partial x} = A'(x) ‚àÇc‚àÇy‚Äã=D‚Ä≤(c)‚àÇb‚àÇc‚Äã=C‚Ä≤(b)‚àÇa‚àÇb‚Äã=B‚Ä≤(a)‚àÇx‚àÇa‚Äã=A‚Ä≤(x)/n/nSo if you multiply jacobian with vector you will get gradient/n/nF‚Ä≤(x)=‚àÇy‚àÇx=[‚àÇy‚àÇx1‚ãØ‚àÇy‚àÇxn] F'(x) = \frac{\partial y}{\partial x} = \left[\frac{\partial y}{\partial x_1} \cdots \frac{\partial y}{\partial x_n}\right] F‚Ä≤(x)=‚àÇx‚àÇy‚Äã=[‚àÇx1‚Äã‚àÇy‚Äã‚ãØ‚àÇxn‚Äã‚àÇy‚Äã]/n/nYou might now from your linear algebra class that if you multiplion is associative, so we mutiply this jacobian chain from any side you want,/n/n‚àÇy‚àÇc‚ãÖ(‚àÇc‚àÇb‚ãÖ(‚àÇb‚àÇa‚ãÖ(‚àÇa‚àÇx)))=(((‚àÇy‚àÇc)‚ãÖ‚àÇc‚àÇb)‚ãÖ‚àÇb‚àÇa)‚ãÖ‚àÇa‚àÇx \frac{\partial y}{\partial c} \cdot \left(\frac{\partial c}{\partial b} \cdot \left(\frac{\partial b}{\partial a} \cdot \left(\frac{\partial a}{\partial x}\right)\right)\right) = \left(\left( \left( \frac{\partial y}{\partial c} \right) \cdot \frac{\partial c}{\partial b}\right) \cdot \frac{\partial b}{\partial a}\right) \cdot \frac{\partial a}{\partial x} ‚àÇc‚àÇy‚Äã‚ãÖ(‚àÇb‚àÇc‚Äã‚ãÖ(‚àÇa‚àÇb‚Äã‚ãÖ(‚àÇx‚àÇa‚Äã)))=(((‚àÇc‚àÇy‚Äã)‚ãÖ‚àÇb‚àÇc‚Äã)‚ãÖ‚àÇa‚àÇb‚Äã)‚ãÖ‚àÇx‚àÇa‚Äã/n

# In the context of our chain rule example:

/n/nJVP=‚àÇy‚àÇc‚ãÖ(‚àÇc‚àÇb‚ãÖ(‚àÇb‚àÇa‚ãÖ(‚àÇa‚àÇx‚ãÖv))) JVP = \frac{\partial y}{\partial c} \cdot \left(\frac{\partial c}{\partial b} \cdot \left(\frac{\partial b}{\partial a} \cdot \left(\frac{\partial a}{\partial x} \cdot v \right)\right)\right) JVP=‚àÇc‚àÇy‚Äã‚ãÖ(‚àÇb‚àÇc‚Äã‚ãÖ(‚àÇa‚àÇb‚Äã‚ãÖ(‚àÇx‚àÇa‚Äã‚ãÖv)))/n/nJVP propagates derivatives forward through the computational graph, from inputs to outputs./n/nwe can cacluating gradient in same direction as function evaluation A->B->C->D , dA->dB->dC->dD/n

# VJP=vT‚ãÖJ \text{VJP} = v^T \cdot J VJP=vT‚ãÖJ

/n/nWhere $v^T$ is the transpose of vector $v$ and $J$ is the Jacobian matrix./n

# In the context of our chain rule example:

/n/nVJP=(((vT‚ãÖ‚àÇy‚àÇc)‚ãÖ‚àÇc‚àÇb)‚ãÖ‚àÇb‚àÇa)‚ãÖ‚àÇa‚àÇx VJP = \left(\left(\left(v^T \cdot \frac{\partial y}{\partial c}\right) \cdot \frac{\partial c}{\partial b}\right) \cdot \frac{\partial b}{\partial a}\right) \cdot \frac{\partial a}{\partial x} VJP=(((vT‚ãÖ‚àÇc‚àÇy‚Äã)‚ãÖ‚àÇb‚àÇc‚Äã)‚ãÖ‚àÇa‚àÇb‚Äã)‚ãÖ‚àÇx‚àÇa‚Äã/n/nVJP propagates derivatives backward through the computational graph, from outputs to inputs. This is the basis for the backpropagation algorithm commonly used in training neural networks./n

# Forward Mode Autodiff (JVP)

/n/nforward mode auto diff really easy. we will box values and its derivative (init 1). as we calculate function in forward direction we will also calculate its derivative./n/nclass JVPBox(Box): def __init__(self, interpretor: Interpreter, primal, tangent) -> None: super().__init__() self._interpreter = interpretor self.primal = primal self.tangent = tangent def __repr__(self): return f"JVPBox (primal={self.primal}, tangent={self.tangent})"/n/nvalues is called primal and its derivative is called tangent./n/nwhen you have function f(x) = sin(x) its derivate is denoted by slope of tangent line at that point. as each point slopes changes this changes are define by gradient function. so although we get derivative of sin(x) at primal point x by using cos(x) we call it tangent. it suppose to indicate slope of tangent line at that point./n

# We will define rules for each primitive operation.

/n/nnote now to define this rule you can only use primitive function, so whole operation need to be closed under composition. eg only on cos define above not math.cos(x)/n/nclass JVPRules: def __init__(self): self.rules = { OPS.ADD: self.add, OPS.MUL: self.mul, OPS.NEG: self.neg, OPS.RECIP: self.recip, OPS.EXP: self.exp, OPS.SIN: self.sin, } def __getitem__(self, op): return self.rules[op] def add(primals, tangents): (x, y), (x_dot, y_dot) = primals, tangents return (x + y,), (x_dot + y_dot,) def mul(primals, tangents): (x, y), (x_dot, y_dot) = primals, tangents return (x * y,), (x_dot * y + x * y_dot,) def neg(primals, tangents): (x,), (x_dot,) = primals, tangents return (-x,), (-x_dot,) def recip(primals, tangents): (x,), (x_dot,) = primals, tangents y = 1 / x return (y,), (-y * y * x_dot,) def exp(primals, tangents): (x,), (x_dot,) = primals, tangents y = exp(x) return (y,), (y * x_dot,) def sin(primals, tangents): (x,), (x_dot,) = primals, tangents return (sin(x),), (cos(x) * x_dot,)/n

# JVP Interpreter

/n/nNow for our first real interpreter. We are boxing values and its tangent. at first we will unbox values, and process this primals and tangents. then we will box the result./n/nclass JVPInterpreter(Interpreter): def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): super().__init__(*args, **kwargs) self.rules = JVPRules() def pure(self, val): return JVPBox(self, val, 0.0) def process_primitive(self, prim, boxes, params): primals = [box.primal for box in boxes] tangents = [box.tangent for box in boxes] op = self.rules[prim] primals_out, tangents_out = op(primals, tangents, **params) result = [] for p, t in zip(primals_out, tangents_out): result.append(JVPBox(self, p, t)) return result/n/njvp simple is function that takes function and its input and its tangent and return the function output and its tangent./n/ndef jvp_simple(func, primals, tangents): with interpreter_context(JVPInterpreter) as iptr: box_in = [JVPBox(iptr, x, t) for x, t in zip(primals, tangents)] out = func(*box_in) box_out = full_raise(iptr, out) primal_out, tangent_out = box_out.primal, box_out.tangent return primal_out, tangent_out def func(x): return sin(x) + exp(x) x,xdot = 3.14,1 y,y_dot = jvp_simple(func, (x,), (xdot,)) print(y,y_dot)/n

# 23.10545951163867 22.103868126994644

/n/nNow lets define wrapper function that will take function. modify inputs do the jvp and return the gradient./n/ndef deriv(function): def jvp_forward(input_value): _, gradient = jvp_simple(function, (input_value,), (1,)) return gradient return jvp_forward/n/ndef func(x): return sin(x) x = 3.14 print(func(x)) deriv_func = deriv(func) print(deriv_func(x))/n

# we get double derivative or hessian

/n/nWhats is happening here is we are double boxing values, BOX2( BOX1(primal, derv1), derv2 ), But since function are closed under composition we can compose derv arbaritary many times,/n

# f(x)=x‚ãÖsin(x) f(x) = x \cdot sin(x) f(x)=x‚ãÖsin(x)

/n/nimport matplotlib.pyplot as plt import random plt.style.use("dark_background") plt.figure(figsize=(10,5)) def forward(func, vec): return [func(x) for x in vec] x = [i / 10 for i in range(-50, 50)] def func(x): return x*sin(x) primals = forward(func, x) f_prime = forward(deriv(func), x) f_prime2 = forward(deriv(deriv(func)), x) f_prime3 = forward(deriv(deriv(deriv(func))), x) f_prime4 = forward(deriv(deriv(deriv(deriv(func)))), x) plt.plot(x, primals, label='f(x) = x*sin(x)') plt.plot(x, f_prime, label="f'(x)") plt.plot(x, f_prime2, label="f''(x)") plt.plot(x, f_prime3, label="f'''(x)") plt.plot(x, f_prime4, label="f''''(x)") plt.grid(True, linestyle="--", alpha=0.15) plt.box(False) plt.legend(loc='upper right') plt.show()/n

# Reverse Mode Automatic Differentiation (VJP)

/n/nIn way add added extra infomation via boxing values with tangent in jvp, in vjp we will add extra infomation node. this will create graph that can be traversed in reverse direction. Hance reverse mode autodiff./n/nReverse mode autodiff is has good explaination on internet,twitter if flooded with i implimeted auto diff in x. so I wont explain this in detail. best explantion imo is karpathy (senpai) link. what this you will get whats going on here./n/ndefine node that will keep backward pass function and its parents nodes/n/nclass Node: def __init__(self, vjp: Callable, parents: list[Node]) -> None: self.vjp = vjp self.parents = parents def is_leaf(self): return len(self.parents) == 0 def get_leaf_nodes() -> Node: return Node(None, [])/n

# rules of backward pass

/n/nOne important thing to note is that even in backward pass we only call primitive functions that we defined. unlike pytorch where you can do what ever shinanigans you want in backward pass. in jax your backward pass need to closed under composition./n/nas a result torch is relatively easy to extend (FAFO) while jax is not./n/nclass VJPRules: def __init__(self): self.rules = { OPS.ADD: self.add, OPS.MUL: self.mul, OPS.NEG: self.neg, OPS.RECIP: self.recip, OPS.EXP: self.exp, OPS.SIN: self.sin, } """ Jax define one of vjp or jvp rules it derives one from the other but this is much more simple to understand """ def __getitem__(self, op): return self.rules[op] def add(self, primals): x, y = primals def vjp_add(grad): return grad, grad return (x + y,), vjp_add def mul(self, primals): x, y = primals def vjp_mul(grad): return grad * y, grad * x return (x * y,), vjp_mul def tanh(self, primals): (x,) = primals y = tanh(x) def vjp_tanh(grad): return ((1 - y * y) * grad,) return (y,), vjp_tanh def neg(self, primals): (x,) = primals def vjp_neg(grad): return (-grad,) return (-x,), vjp_neg def recip(self, primals): (x,) = primals y = 1 / x def vjp_recip(grad): return (-y * y * grad,) return (y,), vjp_recip def exp(self, primals): (x,) = primals y = exp(x) def vjp_exp(grad): return (y * grad,) return (y,), vjp_exp def sin(self, primals): (x,) = primals y = sin(x) def vjp_sin(grad): return (cos(x) * grad,) return (y,), vjp_sin/n

# VJP box where we box primals and its nodes

/n/nclass VJPBox(Box): def __init__(self, interpreter: VJPInterpreter, primal, node: Node) -> None: super().__init__() self._interpreter = interpreter self.primal = primal self.node = node def pure(self,value): return VJPBox(self._interpreter, value, get_leaf_nodes()) def __repr__(self): return f"VJPBox (primal={self.primal}, node={self.node})" class VJPInterpreter(Interpreter): def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): super().__init__(*args, **kwargs) self.rules = VJPRules() def pure(self, val): return VJPBox(self, val, get_leaf_nodes()) def process_primitive(self, prim, boxes, params): primals_in = [box.primal for box in boxes] nodes_in = [box.node for box in boxes] op = self.rules[prim] primals_out, vjp_out = op(primals_in, **params) nodes_out = [Node(vjp_out, nodes_in)] result = [] for p, n in zip(primals_out, nodes_out): result.append(VJPBox(self, p, n)) return result/n/nforward pass will give output and graph, this will be used in backward pass to get the gradient. again watch the karpathy video to get the intuition./n/ndef toposort(end_node): def _toposort(seen, node): result = [] if id(node) not in seen: seen.add(id(node)) for p in node.parents: result.extend(_toposort(seen, p)) result.append(node) return result return reversed([n for n in _toposort(set(), end_node) if n.parents]) def add_grads(grad1, grad2): if grad1 is None: return grad2 return grad1 + grad2 def backward_pass(in_nodes, out_node, gradient): node_map = {id(out_node): gradient} topo_sorted = toposort(out_node) for node in topo_sorted: node_grad = node_map.pop(id(node)) input_grads = node.vjp(node_grad) for input_grad, parent in zip(input_grads, node.parents): parent_id = id(parent) node_map[parent_id] = add_grads(node_map.get(parent_id), input_grad) return [node_map.get(id(node)) for node in in_nodes]/n/nNow simple VJP function that will take function, add leaf nodes to all inputs and return the output and backward function./n/ndef vjp_simple(func, *args): with interpreter_context(VJPInterpreter) as iptr: box_in = [VJPBox(iptr, x, get_leaf_nodes()) for x in args] out = func(*box_in) box_out = full_raise(iptr, out) in_nodes = [box.node for box in box_in] out_node = box_out.node primal_out = box_out.primal def func_vjp(grad): return backward_pass(in_nodes, out_node, grad) return primal_out, func_vjp/n

# grad is small wrapper around vjp

/n/ndef grad(func): def grad_func(*args): _, backward = vjp_simple(func, *args) return backward(1)[0] return grad_func def func(x): return 3 * x * x * x + 2 * x * x + 2 * x print(grad(func)(2)) print(grad(grad(func))(2))/n/nAgain you can take arbitrary derivative of function, for example/n/ndef func(x): return tanh(x) def forward(func, vec): return [func(x) for x in vec] x = [i / 25 for i in range(-100, 100)] plt.figure(figsize=(15,8)) primals = forward(func, x) f_prime = forward(deriv(func), x) f_prime2 = forward(deriv(deriv(func)), x) f_prime3 = forward(deriv(deriv(deriv(func))), x) f_prime4 = forward(deriv(deriv(deriv(deriv(func)))), x) plt.plot(x, primals, label='f(x) = x*sin(x)') plt.plot(x, f_prime, label="f'(x)") plt.plot(x, f_prime2, label="f''(x)") plt.plot(x, f_prime3, label="f'''(x)") plt.plot(x, f_prime4, label="f''''(x)") plt.grid(True, linestyle="--", alpha=0.15) plt.box(False) plt.legend(loc='upper right') plt.show()/n

# Function composition

/n/nsince jvp and vjp are both defined in terms of primitive functions, you can do backward on forward mode autodiff./n/ndef func(x): return sin(x)+ tanh(x)*exp(x) print("forward on backward") print(deriv(grad(func))(2)) print("backward on forward") print(grad(deriv(func))(2))/n

# forward on backward 6.251514736700764 backward on forward 6.251514736700765

/n/nNow there is problem you can only pass primitive data types to functions, eg/n/ndef func(inputs): x,y = inputs return tanh(x) + y inputs = (6,9) grad = deriv(func)/n

# If you run this you will get error,

/n/n1 def func(inputs): ----> 2 x,y = inputs 3 return tanh(x) + y TypeError: cannot unpack non-iterable JVPBox object/n/nwe want box values inside inputs list, but here our list is itself boxed Box(list([x,y])) , we need something like [Box(x),Box(y)] enter the pytree./n/nPytree/n/nPytree is a data structure that represents nested data. Its solve problem of boxing and unboxing values. any take any data structure and convert it to flatten and pytree. now this flatten is just list of primitive datatypes so we can loop over them and box it. tree preserve the structure of the data so after boxing values we can reconstruct the original data structure with each values boxed./n/nfrom __future__ import annotations import numpy as np import numbers from typing import Any, Hashable, Iterable PyTreeTypes = list | dict | tuple | Any/n

# Each pytree has a type, metadata and child tree.

/n/ntype is the type of the data structure, metadata is the data itself and child tree is the child tree of the data structure./n/nclass PyNode: def __init__( self, node_type: type, metadata: Hashable = None, child_tree: "PyNode" = None ): self.node_type = node_type self.metadata = metadata self.child_tree = child_tree def __repr__(self): s = f"({self.node_type.__name__ if self.node_type !='leaf' else 'leaf'}" if isinstance(self.metadata, np.ndarray) or self.metadata: s += f":{self.metadata.__class__.__name__}" if self.child_tree is not None: s += f",{self.child_tree}" return s + ")" def from_iter(pytree) -> tuple[Hashable, "PyNode"]: raise NotImplementedError("Not implemented") def to_iter() -> PyTreeTypes: raise NotImplementedError("Not implemented") def __eq__(self, other: PyNode) -> bool: if self.node_type != other.node_type: return False if self.child_tree != other.child_tree: return False return True class ListNode(PyNode): def to_iter(lst): return None, lst def from_iter(_, iterable): return list(iterable) class DictNode(PyNode): def from_iter(keys, vals): return dict(zip(keys, vals)) def to_iter(dct): keys, values = [], [] for key, value in sorted(dct.items()): keys.append(key) values.append(value) return keys, values class TupleNode(PyNode): def from_iter(_, tup): return tuple(tup) def to_iter(tup): return None, tup node_types: dict[Hashable, PyNode | None] = { list: ListNode, dict: DictNode, tuple: TupleNode, }/n

# Now we will define tree_flatten and tree_unflatten.

/n/ntree_flatten will take any data structure and convert it to flatten and pytree./n/ntree_unflatten will take flatten list and pytree and convert it to original data structure./n/ndef tree_flatten(x: Any) -> tuple[list[Any], PyNode]: def _flatten(x: Any) -> tuple[Iterable, PyNode]: data_type = type(x) node_type = node_types.get(data_type) if node_type is None: return [x], PyNode(node_type="leaf", metadata=x, child_tree=None) node_metadata, children = node_type.to_iter(x) children_flat, child_trees = [], [] for node in children: flat, tree = _flatten(node) children_flat.extend(flat) child_trees.append(tree) subtree = PyNode( data_type, node_metadata, tuple(child_trees), ) return children_flat, subtree flatten, pytree = _flatten(x) return flatten, pytree def tree_unflatten(flattened_list: list, tree: PyNode) -> Any: def _unflatten(flattened_list: list, tree: PyNode) -> Any: if tree.node_type == "leaf": return next(flattened_list) children = [] for child_tree in tree.child_tree: children.append(_unflatten(flattened_list, child_tree)) node_type = node_types[tree.node_type] return node_type.from_iter(tree.metadata, children) return _unflatten(iter(flattened_list[:]), tree) def display_tree(node: PyNode, indent: str = "") -> None: if node.node_type == "leaf": print(f"{indent}Leaf: {node.metadata}") else: node_type_name = node.node_type.__name__ if node.node_type != "leaf" else "leaf" print(f"{indent}{node_type_name}: {node.metadata}") for child in node.child_tree: display_tree(child, indent + " ") if __name__ == "__main__": x = [1, (2, {"a": 3, "b": 4}, 5), [6, 7]] flattened, tree = tree_flatten(x) print(x) print("\nTree structure:") display_tree(tree) print("\n") print("Flattened:", flattened) print("\n") reconstructed = tree_unflatten(flattened, tree) print("\nReconstructed:", reconstructed) assert x == reconstructed, "Reconstruction failed" print("Reconstruction successful!")/n/n[1, (2, {'a': 3, 'b': 4}, 5), [6, 7]] Tree structure: list: None Leaf: 1 tuple: None Leaf: 2 dict: ['a', 'b'] Leaf: 3 Leaf: 4 Leaf: 5 list: None Leaf: 6 Leaf: 7 Flattened: [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7] Reconstructed: [1, (2, {'a': 3, 'b': 4}, 5), [6, 7]] Reconstruction successful!/n/nWe have way to flatten and unflatten any data structure, now we need to flatten and unflatten function. we will create a function that takes function and pytree and return new function and store. ones you evaluate function it will store the pytree of the functions output./n/n(simplified: this will convert function to function that takes flatten list and return flatten list)/n/ndef flatten_fun(func, in_tree): store = {} def flat_fun(*args_flat): pytree_args = tree_unflatten(args_flat, in_tree) out = func(*pytree_args) out_flat, out_tree = tree_flatten(out) assert len(store) == 0, "Store already has a value!" store["tree"] = out_tree return out_flat return flat_fun, store/n

# Some helper functions

/n/ndef nested_ones_like(item): """Create a nested structure of ones with the same shape as the input.""" if isinstance(item, list): return [nested_ones_like(x) for x in item] if isinstance(item, tuple): return tuple(nested_ones_like(x) for x in item) if isinstance(item, dict): return {k: nested_ones_like(v) for k, v in item.items()} return 1.0 if isinstance(item, numbers.Number) else np.ones_like(item) def nested_zero_like(item): """Create a nested structure of zeros with the same shape as the input.""" if isinstance(item, list): return [nested_zero_like(x) for x in item] if isinstance(item, tuple): return tuple(nested_zero_like(x) for x in item) if isinstance(item, dict): return {k: nested_zero_like(v) for k, v in item.items()} return 0.0 if isinstance(item, numbers.Number) else np.zeros_like(item)/n/nNow we will reimplement jvp and vjp using pytree. first we will take function as input and flatten it. when we need to evaluate function we will flatten the input and pass it to the function. then we will unflatten the output and return it./n/ndef jvp_flat(func, primals, tangents): with interpreter_context(JVPInterpreter) as iptr: tracers_in = [JVPBox(iptr, x, t) for x, t in zip(primals, tangents)] outs = func(*tracers_in) tracers_out = [full_raise(iptr, out) for out in outs] primals_out, tangents_out = [], [] for t in tracers_out: primals_out.append(t.primal) tangents_out.append(t.tangent) return primals_out, tangents_out def jvp(func, primals, tangents): primals_flat, in_tree = tree_flatten(primals) tangents_flat, in_tree2 = tree_flatten(tangents) assert in_tree == in_tree2, "Input trees for primals and tangents must match" func_flat, out_tree = flatten_fun(func, in_tree) primals_out_flat, tangents_out_flat = jvp_flat( func_flat, primals_flat, tangents_flat ) assert len(out_tree) == 1, "out tree dict must have only one item" out_tree: PyNode = out_tree["tree"] primals_out = tree_unflatten(primals_out_flat, out_tree) tangents_out = tree_unflatten(tangents_out_flat, out_tree) return primals_out, tangents_out def deriv(func, argnums=0): if isinstance(argnums, int): argnums = [argnums] def jvp_forward(*input_value): tangents = tuple( nested_ones_like(x) if idx in argnums else nested_zero_like(x) for idx, x in enumerate(input_value) ) _, gradient = jvp(func, input_value, tangents) return gradient return jvp_forward def func(x, y): k = tanh(x) * 2.0 + y * y z0 = -y + k z1 = y*k return {" lets": z0,"f*in":z1, "go!": [x, y]} print("## pytree.py ##") x = 3.14 y = 2.71 print(deriv(func, argnums=0)(x, y))/n

# Same for vjp

/n/ndef add_grads(grad1, grad2): if grad1 is None: return grad2 return grad1 + grad2 def toposort(end_nodes): def _toposort(seen, node): result = [] if node not in seen: seen.add(node) for p in node.parents: result.extend(_toposort(seen, p)) result.append(node) return result outs = [] seen = set() topo_sorted = [] for end_node in end_nodes: topo_sorted.extend(_toposort(seen, end_node)) for node in topo_sorted: if node.parents: outs.append(node) result = reversed(outs) return list(result) def backward_pass(in_nodes, out_nodes, gradient): node_map = {out_node: g for g, out_node in zip(gradient, out_nodes)} topo_sorted = toposort(out_nodes) for node in topo_sorted: node_grad = node_map.pop(node) input_grads = node.vjp(node_grad) for input_grad, parent in zip(input_grads, node.parents): node_map[parent] = add_grads(node_map.get(parent), input_grad) return [node_map.get(node) for node in in_nodes] def vjp_flat(func, args): with interpreter_context(VJPInterpreter) as iptr: box_in = [VJPBox(iptr, x, get_leaf_nodes()) for x in args] outs = func(*box_in) box_out = [full_raise(iptr, o) for o in outs] in_nodes = [box.node for box in box_in] out_nodes = [box.node for box in box_out] out_primals = [box.primal for box in box_out] def func_vjp(grad): return backward_pass(in_nodes, out_nodes, grad) return out_primals, func_vjp def vjp(func, primals): primals_flat, in_tree = tree_flatten(primals) func_flat, out_tree = flatten_fun(func, in_tree) primals_out_flat, vjp_func = vjp_flat( func_flat, primals_flat, ) assert len(out_tree) == 1, "out tree dict must have only one item" out_tree: PyNode = out_tree["tree"] primals_out = tree_unflatten(primals_out_flat, out_tree) return primals_out, vjp_func def grad(func, argnums=0): if isinstance(argnums, int): argnums = [argnums] def vjp_func(*input_value): result, vjp_func = vjp(func, input_value) ones = nested_ones_like(result) flat, _ = tree_flatten(ones) grads = vjp_func(flat) _, in_tree = tree_flatten(input_value) grads = tree_unflatten(grads, in_tree) grads = tuple(g for idx, g in enumerate(grads) if idx in argnums) return grads[0] if len(argnums) == 1 else grads return vjp_func def value_and_grad(func, argnums=0): if isinstance(argnums, int): argnums = [argnums] def vjp_forward(*input_value): result, vjp_func = vjp(func, input_value) ones = nested_ones_like(result) flat, _ = tree_flatten(ones) grads = vjp_func(flat) output, in_tree = tree_flatten(input_value) grads = tree_unflatten(grads, in_tree) grads = tuple(g for idx, g in enumerate(grads) if idx in argnums) return result, grads[0] if len(argnums) == 1 else grads return vjp_forward/n/nNow you can do stuff like this, where you pass state dict and get grad for that state dict, and build complex differentiable program./n/ndef linear(state,inputs): weight,bias = state["weights"], state["bias"] total = 0 for w, x in zip(weight, inputs): prod = w * x total = total + prod return total + bias state = {"weights":[1,2,3], "bias": 1} inputs = [0.3, 0.5, 0.7] print(grad(linear)(state,inputs))/n

title: Using ü§ó to Train a GPT-2 Model for Music Generation
summary: Write a comprehensive tutorial on training a GPT-2 model for music generation using the Hugging Face ecosystem, covering dataset preparation, tokenization, model training, hyperparameter tuning, and deploying the model as an interactive demo, while also considering the ethical implications of AI-generated music.
origin_content:
# Introduction

In this tutorial, I'll walk you through the steps to create a Space similar to this one:/n/nü§ó offers a comprehensive set of tools, from dataset creation to model demo deployment. You'll utilize these tools throughout this tutorial. Therefore, familiarity with the Hugging Face ecosystem will be beneficial. By the end of this tutorial, you will be able to train a GPT-2 model for music generation./n/nThis tutorial is inspired by and builds upon the outstanding work of Dr. Tristan Behrens./n/nOverview/n/nGenerative AI is currently trending in the machine learning field. Impressive models such as ChatGPT or Stable Diffusion have captivated the tech community and the general public with their remarkable capabilities. Major companies like Facebook, OpenAI, and Stability AI have also ventured into this movement by releasing impressive music-generation tools./n/nThere are usually two common approaches for generative music models. You can think of them in the following terms:/n/nRaw audio: In this approach, you use the audio raw representation (.wav, .mp3) to train the model. StableAudio and MusicGen use this method./n/nSymbolic music: Rather than using the raw audio representation, you can leverage the instructions that generate that audio. For instance, instead of using the recording of a flute melody, you'd use the score read by the musician to play the tune. MIDI or MusicXML files store the instructions needed to produce a specific piece of music. OpenAI trained MuseNet (no longer available) with symbolic music./n/nThe focus of this tutorial is on symbolic models. Specifically, you'll implement a clever idea: If you can convert the instructions included in symbolic music files (MIDI files for this tutorial) into words, you could leverage the tremendous advancements in NLP to train your model!/n

# Collecting the Dataset and Converting It to Words

/n/nNote: Given the extensive size of the MIDI files required, I've curated a ready-to-use dataset available on Hugging Face. Alternatively, if you'd prefer a smaller dataset, you can utilize the JS Fake Chorales dataset to follow this tutorial./n/nCollecting the dataset and having it ready for training is the hardest part of the project. Fortunately, people have shared some MIDI collections on the Internet that you can use. You will use one of these collections curated by Colin Raffel, the Lakh MIDI dataset (LMD), which includes 176,581 unique MIDI files. From the LDM, you will use the Clean MIDI subset (14,751 files) with filenames indicating the artist and title./n

# Getting the Genres

/n/nKnowing the artist and title of each file enables you to determine the song's genre. There are many approaches to do this. I used a mixed method where I first used the Spotify API to get the genres based on the artist and then ChatGPT to group them into a final set of more or less balanced genres./n/ngenres = {} for i,artist in enumerate(artists): try: results = sp.search(q=artist, type='artist',limit=1) items = results['artists']['items'] genre_list = items[0]['genres'] if len(items) else items['genres'] genres[artist] = (genre_list[0]).replace(" ", "_") if i < 5: print("INFO: Preview {}/5".format(i + 1), artist, genre_list[:5]) except Exception as e: genres[artist] = "MISC" print("INFO: ", artist, "not included: ", e)/n/nThe results are far from perfect, but they are close enough to work for controlling our model. The final CSV file with the genres is available on GitHub./n/nWhy should you get the genres? You could use the genres to incorporate a token/n/n"GENRE={NAME_OF_GENRE}"/n/ninto the input sequence that moves the generation process to that specific genre, as you will see next./n

# Tokenizing the Dataset

/n/nThe image above shows you one way to convert music instructions into tokens: Exactly what you want to train a language model! In this section, you'll discover how to transition from a MIDI file to a text-based format using pseudo-words (terms that aren't part of the English vocabulary) for training your GPT-2 model./n

# Chunking the Dataset

/n/nIn this tutorial, you will tokenize each file in 8-bar windows where each 'bar' is a segment containing a specified number of beats. Play with other numbers, such as 4 or 16, to see how the result changes. There are many ways to do this, but for simplicity, let's loop over the dataset and create a new MIDI file that is 8-bar long. I used the following code in Colab for doing the chunking./n/nfor i, midi_path in enumerate(tqdm(midi_paths, desc="CHUNKING MIDIS")): try: relative_path = midi_path.relative_to(Path("path/to/dataset/lmd", dataset)) output_dir = merged_out_dir / relative_path.parent output_dir.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True) chunk_paths = list(output_dir.glob(f"{midi_path.stem}_*.mid")) if len(chunk_paths) > 0: print(f"Chunks for {midi_path} already exist, skipping...") continue midi = MidiFile(midi_path) ticks_per_cut = MAX_NB_BAR * midi.ticks_per_beat * 4 nb_cuts = ceil(midi.max_tick / ticks_per_cut) if nb_cuts < 2: continue print(f"Processing {midi_path}") midis = [deepcopy(midi) for _ in range(nb_cuts)] for j, track in enumerate(midi.instruments): track.notes.sort(key=lambda x: x.start) for midi_short in midis: midi_short.instruments[j].notes = [] for note in track.notes: cut_id = note.start // ticks_per_cut note_copy = deepcopy(note) note_copy.start -= cut_id * ticks_per_cut note_copy.end -= cut_id * ticks_per_cut midis[cut_id].instruments[j].notes.append(note_copy) for j, midi_short in enumerate(midis): if sum(len(track.notes) for track in midi_short.instruments) < MIN_NB_NOTES: continue midi_short.dump(output_dir / f"{midi_path.stem}_{j}.mid") except Exception as e: print(f"An error occurred while processing {midi_path}: {e}")/n/nI added a simplified version of the code. You can take a look at the complete notebook./n

# From MIDI Instructions to Words

/n/nHaving segmented each song into 8-bar MIDI files, you're now ready to transform these files into pseudo-words. Researchers have proposed different music tokenization methods, among the most popular you can find:/n/nREMI/n/nREMIPlus/n/nMIDI-Like/n/nCPWord/n/nMMM/n/nYou can find an excellent overview of different tokenizers in the docs of MidiTok, a powerful Python package to tokenize MIDI music files./n/nTokenization/n/nTempo/n

# Pitch bend

/n/nMIDILike/n/n‚úÖ/n/n‚úÖ/n/n‚úÖ/n/n‚úÖ/n/n‚úÖ/n/n‚úÖ/n/nREMI/n/n‚úÖ/n/n‚úÖ/n/n‚úÖ/n/n‚úÖ/n/n‚úÖ/n/n‚úÖ/n/nTSD/n/n‚úÖ/n/n‚úÖ/n/n‚úÖ/n/n‚úÖ/n/n‚úÖ/n/n‚úÖ/n/nStructured/n/n‚ùå/n/n‚ùå/n/n‚ùå/n/n‚ùå/n/n‚ùå/n/n‚ùå/n/nCPWord/n/n‚úÖ/n/n‚úÖ/n/n‚úÖ/n/n‚úÖ/n/n‚ùå/n/n‚ùå/n/nOctuple/n/n‚úÖ/n/n‚úÖ/n/n‚ùå/n/n‚ùå/n/n‚ùå/n/n‚ùå/n/nMuMIDI/n/n‚úÖ/n/n‚ùå/n/n‚úÖ/n/n‚ùå/n/n‚ùå/n/n‚ùå/n/nMMM/n/n‚úÖ/n/n‚úÖ/n/n‚úÖ/n/n‚ùå/n/n‚ùå/n/n‚ùå/n/nYou will use the MMM: Multi-Track Music Machine tokenization method for this tutorial. MMM is a simple yet powerful approach to convert MIDI files to pseudo-words. Try other tokenizers and compare the results. Please let me know which is your favorite tokenizer üòÄ./n

# MMM: Multi-Track Music Machine

/n/nJeff Ens and Philippe Pasquier presented the MMM tokenizer in the paper MMM: Exploring Conditional Multi-Track Music Generation with the Transformer. Look at the following illustration from the paper to have a better understanding of this method:/n/nIn MMM, the numbers represent the pitch of the notes and the instruments in MIDI notation. For example, in the diagram above, the NOTE_ON=60 is the C4, and the INST=30 means an Overdriven Guitar. You use NOTE_ON/NOTE_OFF to indicate when the note starts and stops sounding and TIME_DELTA to move the timeline. The notes are wrapped inside <BAR_START> and <BAR_END> tokens which are added inside <TRACK_START> and <TRACK_END> pseudo-words that you finally group inside <PIECE_START> and <PIECE_END>: MultriTrack Music Machine!/n/nLet's illustrate this with a specific example taken from JS Fake Chorales:/n/nI hope this concise overview provides clarity on how MMM operates. Now, to the fun part! Let's take the LMD Clean and convert it to pseudo-words./n/nTo tokenize the dataset, you can leverage open-source libraries like MidiTok (mentioned above) or Musicaiz. Both offer great features to customize your tokenization process. However, I decided to use the MMM-JSB repo as a starting point and adapt it to the Lakh Midi Dataset because I could have more control over the process. You can find the adapted repo here./n/nThe adapted repo removes files with multiple time signatures or times signatures that are not 4/4. Besides, it adds a GENRE= token so you can control in inference the genre you want your model to generate. Finally, I decided not to quantize the notes so the sounds are less robotic./n/nYou can utilize this notebook for dataset tokenization. However, be mindful that the process can be time-consuming, and you might encounter errors. If you want to skip this process, I uploaded the tokenized dataset to the Hub, and it is ready for you to use! Hugging Face allows you to upload the dataset easily. In my case, I created a data frame to do some cleaning and basic data exploration and uploaded the final data frame as a dataset to the Hub./n/n!pip install datasets import glob dataset_files = glob.glob("/path/to/tokenized/dataset/*.txt") from datasets import load_dataset dataset = load_dataset("text", data_files=dataset_files) ds = dataset["train"] df = ds.to_pandas() from datasets import Dataset clean_dataset = Dataset.from_pandas(df) from huggingface_hub import notebook_login notebook_login() clean_dataset.push_to_hub("juancopi81/mmm_track_lmd_8bars_nots")/n

# Training the Tokenizer and the Model.

/n/nAt this point, your dataset should be formatted into pseudo-words. Remember, you could collect one by following the previous part of the tutorial, or you could use the one prepared on the Hub. You could also use a smaller dataset to test this part of the tutorial or if you are low on resources. For instance, I recommend the js-fakes-4bars dataset as a simpler alternative that will work fine. I'll add links to the respective notebooks based on your chosen dataset (LMD | JS Fake)./n/nSince you now have a dataset of pseudo-words, the next part will be very similar to training a language model, but the language is composed of music words. Indeed, this part of the tutorial heavily follows the Hugging Face NLP course, where you need to train a tokenizer after having a dataset./n/nNote: If you are unfamiliar with tokenization or model training, I encourage you to review the course to understand this tutorial better./n/nTokenizer/n/nColab for following this part of the tutorial: LMD | JS Fake/n/nFor this tutorial, you will be training a GPT-2 model. This model has excellent learning power, is open-source, and Hugging Face has done a great job facilitating its training and usage. But GPT-2 was not trained in a music language, so you must re-training from scratch, starting with the tokenizer./n/nTo illustrate the previous point, let's tokenize some words of our dataset with the default GPT-2 tokenizer:/n
